chapter.summary: Covers which people with delirium do not need admission to hospital; how to treat the underlying cause of delirium in people not needing hospital admission; how to manage confusion and challenging behaviours; what advice, information, and follow up should be offered and how to manage delirium towards the end of life.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I admit, refer, or manage a person with delirium in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Most people with delirium should be admitted to hospital for urgent assessment, close monitoring, and treatment.
    • The decision as to whether to admit or refer a person with delirium to secondary care depends on the person's specific clinical and social situation, and should also take into account the views of family members or carers.
    • If the person is deemed to not have capacity to consent, decisions should be made in the best interests of the person using the Mental Capacity Act 2005. For further information on assessment of capacity and the Mental Capacity Act, see the section on the Mental Capacity Act 2005 in the CKS topic on Dementia.
    • If the person with delirium refuses admission:
      • Ask carers or family (if appropriate) to help persuade the person. If this fails, consider admission under the Mental Capacity Act (2005).
  • Management in primary care may be appropriate if all of the following are present: 
    • The benefits of management in primary care outweigh the benefits of hospital admission, or the person is clinically well enough to stay at home.
    • The symptoms of delirium are not harmful to the person or others, and can be managed safely in primary care.
    • The cause of delirium is known and treatable.
    • The person can receive constant supervision and care from a healthcare professional trained in the management of delirium — to minimize complications.
    • Close clinical follow-up can be arranged.
  • If admission is not appropriate, seek advice from an elderly care consultant or psychiatrist when:
    • There is doubt about the diagnosis — if there is difficulty distinguishing between delirium, dementia, or delirium with dementia, treat for delirium first.
    • The person has severe delirium — they are severely agitated or distressed.
    • Detention under the Mental Health Act (1983, amended 2007) is being considered. For further information, see the section on the Mental Health Act (2007) in the CKS topic on Self-harm.
    • Further investigations which are not available in primary care are needed.
    • The person does not respond to initial treatment in primary care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on which people with delirium to admit, refer, or manage in primary care are based on the clinical guidelines Delirium in medical care of older persons in residential aged care facilities [RACGP, 2006], The prevention, diagnosis and management of delirium in older people: national guidelines [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b], and Delirium: diagnosis, prevention and management [NICE, 2010a], the Healthcare Improvement Scotland toolkit Improving the care for older people: Delirium toolkit [Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014], the position statement from the Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine Delirium in Older people [Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012] and expert opinion in review articles [Meagher, 2001; Chan, 2011; Tullman, 2012; Vidal, 2013; Kalish, 2014; Inouye, 2014; Stephens, 2015].

Take into account the person's specific clinical and social situation
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in review articles [Kalish, 2014; Raju, 2015].
Use of the Mental Capacity Act (2005)
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article [Raju, 2015].
Use of the Mental Health Act (1983, amended 2007) if the person with delirium refuses admission
  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in a review article [Stephens, 2015].
Management in primary care may be appropriate in certain circumstances
  • The recommendations on when management of delirium in primary care may be appropriate are based on expert opinion in review articles [Meagher, 2001; Raju, 2015; Stephens, 2015].
    • Delirium is serious and is often best managed in hospital. However, admitting the person to hospital for care must be balanced against the potentially negative effects of a sudden change in environment on elderly people or those who have cognitive impairment [Meagher, 2001].
    • Management plans should be formulated with the person's and their family and/or carer's overall goals of care and advance directives in mind [Kalish, 2014].
Seeking advice from an elderly care consultant or psychiatrist 
  • The recommendations on when to seek advice from an elderly care consultant or psychiatrist are based on expert opinion in the Delirium toolkit [Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014] and in review articles [Raju, 2015; Stephens, 2015]. 

If it is difficult to distinguish between delirium and dementia, treat for delirium first 

  • This recommendation is based on expert opinion in the NICE guideline Delirium: diagnosis, prevention and management [NICE, 2010a]. 
    • It can be difficult to differentiate between delirium, delirium superimposed on dementia, or dementia alone. As delirium is a reversible and serious acute illness, priority should be given to treating it over a potential underlying dementia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with delirium in primary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If appropriate to manage the person in primary care:

  • Correct any precipitating factors, for example:
    • Infection — for further information, see the CKS topics on Chest infections - adult, Gastroenteritis, Urinary tract infection (lower) - men and Urinary tract infection (lower) - women.
    • Drugs — consider reducing the dose, stopping or substituting medications that can precipitate delirium (such as opioids, benzodiazepines, and anticholinergics). Avoid abrupt withdrawal of drugs which can cause dependence or discontinuation syndromes.
    • Constipation — for further information, see the CKS topic on Constipation.
    • Urinary retention — for further information, see the CKS topic on LUTS in men.
    • Dehydration and electrolyte imbalance — for further information, see the CKS topics on Acute kidney injury, Chronic kidney disease, Hypercalcaemia, and Hyponatraemia. 
    • Pain — treat appropriately with analgesia that is unlikely to worsen the delirium. For further information, see the CKS topic on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain. 
    • Sensory impairment, for example treat impacted ear wax and ensure the person has functioning spectacles, or that hearing aids are available and used if needed. For further information, see the CKS topic on Earwax.
  • Optimize treatment of comorbidities, for example:
    • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease — for more information, see the CKS topic on Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
    • Dementia — for more information, see the CKS topic on Dementia.
    • Diabetes mellitus — for more information, see the CKS topics on Diabetes - type 1 and Diabetes - type 2.
    • Heart failure — for more information, see the CKS topic on Heart failure - chronic.
    • Thyroid disease — for more information, see the CKS topics on Hyperthyroidism and Hypothyroidism.
    • Parkinson's disease — for more information, see the CKS topic on Parkinson's disease.
    • Cerebrovascular disease — for more information, see the CKS topic on Stroke and TIA. 
  • Advise family and carers that they should:
    • Provide simple explanations for all activities in a calm manner.
    • Try reorientation strategies, such as:
      • Regular (at least three times a day) cues (for example explaining to the person who and where they are).
      • Easily visible and accurate clocks and calendars.
      • Continuity of care from carers and nursing staff.
      • Encouraging visits from family or friends and exposure to familiar objects.
    • Maintain safe mobility:
      • Avoid physical restraints such as cot sides. 
      • Encourage walking at least 3 times a day (provide walking aids if needed) or, if the person is unable to mobilize, try active range of motion exercises. 
    • Normalize the sleep-wake cycle by:
      • Discouraging napping and encouraging bright light exposure in the daytime.
      • Encouraging uninterrupted sleep at night with a quiet room and low level lighting.
  • If the person with delirium develops challenging behaviour (such as aggression, agitation, or shouting):
    • Address any underlying causes for the behaviour (such as discomfort, thirst, or need for the toilet).
    • Advise moving the person to a safe, low-stimulation environment (such as a quiet room).
    • Advise use of verbal and non-verbal de-escalation techniques (such as active listening, effective verbal responding, pictures, and symbols).
      • For more information on de-escalation techniques, see the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) pathway on Violence and aggression.
    • If these measures fail, seek advice from an elderly care psychiatrist, challenging behaviour team (if available locally), or elderly care physician.
      • Depending on the specific situation (for example the person is a danger to themselves or to others), short term pharmacological measures may be suggested.
  • If the person with delirium is in the palliative phase of an illness, other measures may be suggested. For further information, see the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.
  • Explain the diagnosis of delirium to the person and their carers and provide written information:
    • Explain delirium is common and usually temporary. 
    • Explain that people with delirium must not drive until symptoms have completely resolved.
    • Ensure that the person has an opportunity to discuss their experience with a member of the primary healthcare team during recovery. 
    • Encourage people at risk and families/carers to seek medical help if a recurrence of delirium is suspected (for example the person develops sudden changes or fluctuations in behaviour).
    • Sources of information and support include:
      • The Royal College of Psychiatrists — this organisation has produced a patient information leaflet on delirium.
      • Carers UK (www.carersuk.org) and the Carers Trust (www.carers.org) — these organisations provide advice, information and support for anyone caring for a sick, frail, disabled, or elderly person at home.
  • Arrange follow up:
    • Review the person within 24 hours of initial assessment and regularly thereafter until symptoms have resolved — adjust the management plan if appropriate. 
    • Arrange admission or seek advice from an elderly care physician or psychiatrist, if the person fails to improve or they deteriorate.
    • Arrange referral, if appropriate, to other healthcare professionals (an elderly care physician or psychiatrist, community psychiatric nurse, occupational therapist, or social worker) depending on the person's specific situation. 
      • If new cognitive impairment is suspected following an episode of delirium, follow local protocols for cognitive impairment assessment. For further information, see the CKS topic on Dementia.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What specialist treatment is available?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Specialists such as elderly care psychiatrists, the challenging behaviour team, or elderly care physicians may suggest pharmacological measures as a last resort for severe agitation or psychosis if [Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012; Stephens, 2015]:
    • Verbal and non-verbal de-escalation techniques are inappropriate or have failed, and 
    • The person is a danger to themselves or others, and 
    • The cause of delirium is known and being treated, and 
    • The benefit outweighs the risk to the person, and 
    • There is enough care in place for the person to be continually monitored. 
  • The following medication may be suggested:
    • Short-term (for 1 week or less) low-dose haloperidol (off-label indication) [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b; NICE, 2010a; Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012; Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014].
    • Low-dose lorazepam (off-label indication) as an alternative if haloperidol is contraindicated (for example in people with Parkinson's disease/parkinsonism, Lewy-body dementia, or a prolonged QT interval) [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b; Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust, 2011; Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014; Kalish, 2014].
      • Antipsychotic drugs should be avoided, or used with caution in Parkinson's disease or dementia with Lewy bodies [NICE quality standard, 2014].
  • If medication is prescribed:
    • The risks (for example with haloperidol, an increased risk of stroke, transient ischaemic attack, and changes in cognition) and benefits (a small reduction in psychosis, aggression, and agitation) of treatment must be discussed with the person and their carers. 
      • Informed consent should be obtained and documented [NHS Evidence, 2012].
    • Start at the lowest clinically appropriate dose and titrate cautiously according to symptoms. For further information, see the section on Prescribing information.
    • The aim of drug treatment is to calm (not sedate) the person.
    • The need for one-to-one supervision and information on when to seek urgent medical help (for example if the person deteriorates, or adverse effects develop) should be explained to carers.

    [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b; NICE, 2010a; Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012; Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014; NICE quality standard, 2014; Inouye, 2014; Kalish, 2014]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of delirium in primary care are based on the clinical guidelines Delirium in medical care of older persons in residential aged care facilities [RACGP, 2006], The prevention, diagnosis and management of delirium in older people: national guidelines [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b] and Delirium: diagnosis, prevention and management [NICE, 2010a], the NICE quality standard Delirium in adults [NICE quality standard, 2014], the Healthcare Improvement Scotland toolkit  Improving the care for older people: Delirium toolkit [Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014], the position statement from the Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine Delirium in Older people [Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012], and expert opinion in review articles [Meagher, 2001; Chan, 2011; Tullman, 2012; Vidal, 2013; Kalish, 2014; Inouye, 2014; Stephens, 2015].

Advice to family and carers
  • The recommendation on what advice to give family and carers is based on clinical guidelines [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b] and [NICE, 2010a], a position statement [Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012], and expert opinion in review articles [Tullman, 2012] and [Inouye, 2014].
  • The recommendation that people with delirium should not drive is based on the Driver and Vehicle Licencing Agency (DVLA) statement that people with 'significant memory or concentration problems, agitation, behavioural disturbance or suicidal thoughts' must not drive. For further information, see the section on Psychiatric disorders: assessing fitness to drive on the DVLA website.
Avoidance of drugs for alleviation of symptoms of aggression
  • The recommendation on avoidance of pharmacological interventions (unless suggested as a last resort by a specialist) is based on clinical guidelines [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b] and [NICE, 2010a], a delirium toolkit [Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014], a position statement [Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012] and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • Serious adverse effects (such as ischaemic stroke, prolongation of QT interval, sudden cardiac death, and pneumonia) are associated with the use of antipsychotic medications (including atypical antipsychotic medications), and as such they should be avoided if possible [Australian and New Zealand Society for Geriatric Medicine, 2012], [MHRA, 2012].
    • Increasing evidence suggests that antipsychotic or sedating medications may prolong the duration of delirium, prolong associated cognitive impairment, and worsen clinical outcome (possibly by converting hyperactive delirium to hypoactive delirium) [Inouye, 2014].
Explain the diagnosis of delirium to the person and their family/carers and provide written information
  • The recommendation on explaining the diagnosis and providing written information is based on clinical guidelines [NICE, 2010a] and [Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust, 2011], the delirium toolkit [Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014], the NICE Quality Standard Delirium in adults [NICE quality standard, 2014], the NICE pathway on delirium [NICE Pathway, 2014], and expert opinion in a review article [Inouye, 2014].
    • The experience of delirium can be distressing especially if the person has flashbacks to hallucinations or delusions once delirium has settled. Information describing other people's experiences of delirium can help support recovery [NICE quality standard, 2014].
Arranging follow-up
  • The recommendation on the follow-up of a person with delirium is based on a clinical guideline [Royal College of Physicians and British Geriatrics Society, 2006b], the delirium toolkit [Healthcare Improvement Scotland, 2014], and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

subChapters.fullItemName: Delirium in end of life care
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage delirium in end of life care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Explore the possible causes of delirium with the dying person and those important to them. Be aware that agitation in isolation is sometimes associated with other unrelieved symptoms or bodily needs for example, unrelieved pain or a full bladder or rectum.
  • Consider non-pharmacological management of delirium in a person in the last days of life.
  • Treat any reversible causes of delirium, for example, psychological causes or certain metabolic disorders (for example renal failure or hyponatraemia).
  • Ensure that suitable anticipatory medicines are prescribed as early as possible. Review these medicines as the dying person's needs change. 
  • Consider a trial of an antipsychotic medicine (such as haloperidol or levomepromazine) to manage delirium. 
  • Monitor the benefits and side effects of these medicines at least daily and adjust the prescription as the clinical situation changes. 
  • Seek specialist advice if the diagnosis of delirium is uncertain, if the delirium does not respond to antipsychotic treatment or if treatment causes unwanted sedation.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence [NICE, 2015a]. The drug recommendations are based on the [Northern England Clinical Networks, 2016].
